Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: UTEP-ROCCS (University of Texas at El Paso - Research Opportunities for Community College Students)
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will provide field and laboratory based research opportunities for 2-year college (2YC) students focusing on a variety of geologic problems in the El Paso region. The 2YC students will be mentored by University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) and El Paso Community College (EPCC) faculty and undergraduate students who have had research experiences and will be trained as student mentors. The summer experience will involve 4 weeks in El Paso followed by 4 weeks at their home institutions with intensive virtual mentoring. The research projects will focus on how the geology and morphology of the El Paso region influence local soil development, surface and groundwater hydrology, and landscape evolution, as well as evolution of the southern Rio Grande Rift. The project will use a model for cognitive change related to social interactions to determine which on-site activities were the most successful at increasing collaboration and the knowledge/skills base of the 2YC students. The model will also assess the quality and degree of interaction between the 2YC participants and their faculty or student mentors. Few REU programs in geosciences specifically target 2YC students to conduct research outside of their community. Thus this REU will serve as a model for other institutions to involve 2YC students in REU projects and the training materials developed will be helpful to other institutions wishing to recruit and retain 2YC students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
UTEP-ROCCS (University of Texas at El Paso-Research Opportunities for Community College Students) was an NSF supported summer research experience designed exclusively for two-year college students from across the United States conducted during the summers of 2017 to 2019.  Unlike many other summer programs, the participants only visited El Paso during the month of June to begin their research projects.  Subsequent research was carried out at their home institutions in July through intensive virtual mentoring.  This program design allowed these students, who often have family or work obligations, to attend with less disruption to their other commitments. All research projects focused on the geology and geophysics of the El Paso region, with most research work carried out on or within 10 miles of the UTEP campus.  The individual research topics of the students included studies of local fossils, geophysical surveys, surface mapping projects, and geochemical and mineralogy analyses.  The mentoring team for the program was a unique mix of two-year and four-year college faculty and undergraduate juniors and seniors.  Over its 3 year lifetime ROCCS hosted 22 two-year college students supported by 7 UTEP undergraduate mentors, 2 undergraduate mentors who had participated in cohorts from previous years, and 9 faculty members from UTEP and El Paso Community College.  Sixty four percent of the ROCCS participants were female and 41% were non-traditional students and/or from underrepresented groups, while 56% of the student mentors were female and 78% were non-traditional students and/or from underrepresented groups.  Weekly surveys administered each year of the program showed that 96% of the time the two-year college participants felt their faculty and student mentors were supportive, encouraging and able to respond to their questions and concerns.  Ninety two percent felt they received constructive, useful critiques of their field research work, were motivated by their mentors to learn more and were challenged to extend their abilities and skills for the success of the research projects.  Over 94% felt the experience stimulated their interest in the geosciences as a future career. Nearly all participants (91%) presented posters on their summer research projects at the virtual poster showcase of the American Geophysical Union, 68% presented posters in person at fall national meetings of the Geological Society of America and 18% presented in person posters at fall meetings of the American Geophysical Union. A May 2020 follow-up survey (with a 91% response rate) indicated 14 participants were currently attending a four-year institution to complete a BS degree in the geosciences, 5 had graduated from a four-year institution and one was employed full-time after obtaining a GIS certificate. Four participants had applied or intended to apply for graduate school.  Of the 9 student mentors, all have completed or will complete a BS degree in geological sciences by spring 2021.  Two are employed full-time and 5 are in graduate school. This program demonstrated that two-year college students who may have only had 2 classes in geological sciences prior to their arrival for the June intensive program were extremely capable of conducting and presenting high quality research. Our use of undergraduate student mentors, many of whom had also started their studies at a two year college, enhanced our ability to support and encourage the two-year participants in their research projects.  Based on these positive outcomes we hope other 4 year institutions will be inspired to initiate similar research opportunities for 2 year college students interested in the geosciences.
